question: Which variables are required to compute the flow between the river and groundwater system for the RIV boundary condition? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. The flow is calculated using groundwater head, river stage, and riverbed properties to determine the water exchange rate. Groundwater system properties are not involved in calculating exchange between groundwater and the river, but head in the groundwater system is controlled by the geometry, hydraulic properties, and boundary conditions of the model.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. The RIV equation uses river stage, groundwater head, and riverbed properties to determine the water exchange rate. Hydraulic properties of the groundwater system are not involved in calculating exchange between groundwater and the river, but head in the groundwater system is controlled by the geometry, hydraulic properties, and boundary conditions of the model.

question: How does increasing the riverbed conductance ($C_{Riv}$) affect flow behavior in a RIV boundary condition? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Higher conductance means better connection with the boundary. A higher conductance results in more flow per unit head difference. A very high conductance will cause head in the groundwater system near the boundary to be almost the same as the boundary head because a large amount of flow will occur for even small head differences.
error: ❌ All responses that indicate increased flow, connection, and sensitivity are correct. Increased sensitivity occurs because higher conductance means the change in flow rate is larger for a given head difference.

question: When does flow between the groundwater system and river stop for the RIV boundary? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Well done. Flow stops if the groundwater system head equals the river stage and/or if conductance is zero. Flow occurs at a constant, non-zero rate when the groundwater system head is lower than the riverbed bottom. Flow is dependent on the difference between river stage and groundwater system head not on the value of river stage.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Flow stops if the groundwater system head equals the river stage and/or if conductance is zero. Flow is constant, not zero, when the groundwater system head is lower than the riverbed bottom. Flow is dependent on the difference between river stage and groundwater system head not on the value of river stage.

question: How does the MODFLOW RIV boundary simulate a gaining stream? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. A gaining stream receives flow when the groundwater system head is above the river stage.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. A stream gains when the groundwater system head is above the river stage and in that case, flow is directed from the groundwater system to the stream. It is true that the boundary head does not depend on the groundwater system head, but that does not cause simulation of a gaining stream. A saturated aquifer may have a head below the stream stage and so will not always cause a stream to gain.

question: What happens to the exchange flow as groundwater system head approaches the river stage elevation from above? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Exactly. The flow becomes minimal as the groundwater head approaches the river stage elevation. It does not become negative because it is negative when water is exiting the groundwater system. When less water exits the flow is still negative.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Flow tapers off but does not reverse and the boundary is not disabled.

question: Which statement about RIV boundaries is true? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. RIV boundaries are bidirectional and governed by head difference and conductance.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. RIV allows bidirectional flow and uses conductance to model exchange. The flow at boundaries is included in the water budget but conditions at boundaries cannot _override_ the budget.
